question: Posted By HRS on April 03, 1999 at 09:11:59:I'm a 53-year-old male.  Prior to 1993, I never evidenced any symptoms of TII diabetes.From 1987 on I was taking medication to help control cholestrol--mevacor primarily.Begining in 1991, I noticed some loss of sensation in my toes and finger tips.By 1995, the loss was more than slight though still isolated to my small toes andthe tips of a few fingers.  In 1996, my 6.3 glucose led one doctor todiagnose me as a Type II diabetic and put me on glucophage.  He explained that the loss of sensationwas due to diabetes.  Throughout this period, no mention was ever madeof my cholestrol medication.Less than two months ago, on the advice of my care-giver, I began a high-protein diet to lose some weight and lower my blood-pressure.  We took ablood baseline.  I discontinued all medication for this program with the aim ofredoing the blood tests after two months.  Several results are immediately apparent:1.  I have lost 25 pounds.2.  My blood pressure has dropped to the 130/85 range.3.  The numbness in my feet and fingers has decreased dramatically.We won't take another blood test for several weeks yet, but I'm curious:Which is a more likely explanation in your opinion for mymy receding peripheral neuropathy: dropping the zocor or changingdiet?
title: Where did it go?
